animations/slime.title: physarum
animations/slime.content:
This animation explores the study of biological computing, specifically the foraging behaviour of the Physarum polycephalum slime mould, which is famous for its ability to optimise pathways across its network. The inspiration for this animation came from Patt Vira‚Äôs video on the topic, who herself was inspired by Jeff Jones‚Äôs algorithm.
The math
The simulation is an agent-based model where emergent complexity arises from three mathematical stages ‚Äî sensing, steering and decaying.
Sensing
Each agent possesses a heading Œ∏(t) and three sensors (left, forward, right) positioned at a distance d from the agent. The spatial coordinates for a sensor at offset angle œï are calculated using
s_x=a_x+d\cos(Œ∏+œï)\\
s_y=a_y+d\sin(Œ∏+œï)
where s is a sensor and a is the agent. The agent ‚Äúsamples‚Äù the trail map at these coordinates to determine the local pheromone concentration C.
Steering
The agent‚Äôs movement is governed by a simple steering rule based on the sampled concentrations C_L, C_F, and C_R. To decide the next heading Œ∏(t+1), the agent follows the gradient of the highest concentration.
If C_F > C_L and C_F > C_R, the agent continues straight, so ŒîŒ∏=0. If C_F < C_L and C_F < C_R, the agent randomly rotates either left or right by the rotation angle Œ±. Otherwise, it rotates toward the side with the higher concentration.
Decay
The environment itself is a dynamic grid. Every frame, the pheromone map undergoes two processes ‚Äî deposition and decay ‚Äî to simulate biological dissipation, with an option third step, diffusion.
As an agent moves to a new pixel, it increases that pixel‚Äôs intensity
C_{new} = C_{old}+ScentStrength
through a process called deposition. Then, to prevent the map from saturating, every pixel value is multiplied by a decay factor Œ≥ (where 0<Œ≥<1).
C(t+1)=C(t)Œ≥
To create smoother paths, the values are then optionally often diffused by averaging them with their neighbours using a Laplacian-like kernel, simulating the natural spreading of chemicals through a medium.
Play with the code!
See the code, change the parameters and try creating your very own Physarum network in the p5.js web editor.

applications/QADDOE.title: QADDOE
applications/QADDOE.content:
QADDOE is a free, open-source desktop Qualitative Data Analysis application that runs on Windows, Mac and Linux. Designed by and for researchers, QADDOE offers a powerful qualitative coding workflow, integral document security and code management without the overhead of unnecessary features.


                  
                  Getting Started 
                  
                

You can download the latest version here or view the source code on GitHub.
Got any questions? Take a peek at the documentation or get in touch.


How QADDOE came to be
The idea for QADDOE grew out of a shared frustration. While working alongside a professor and one of his PhD students at the Universit√© du Qu√©bec √† Trois-Rivi√®res, I saw first-hand how the current state of qualitative data analysis software was holding researchers back. For years, the industry-standard tools have become increasingly bloated and slow. More concerning, however, is how restrictive they‚Äôve become ‚Äî not just by locking users into their ecosystems and export formats, but by forcing researchers to adopt the company‚Äôs own opinionated workflows. Researchers shouldn‚Äôt have to fight their tools to get their work don, so we decided to build a alternative.
Our design ethos
Our philosophy is built on the idea that software should facilitate research rather than dictate it. We embrace a sense of feature-minimalism, focusing entirely on the essential tools needed for rigorous coding and analysis. By avoiding unnecessary features that clutter the interface, we leave the actual control in your hands.
Central to this is the belief that your data should always remain yours. We use open export formats and rely on markdown files (which are essentially text files with formatting) that can be read by any text program. This ensures that your project can be moved to any other software at any time without friction.
We believe the true power of analysis lies with the researcher. Our goal is to empower the user by keeping the software free of charge, easy to use, and open to everyone. Analysis shouldn‚Äôt be a privilege reserved for those with the big budgets. We are committed to continuous improvement, constantly evolving QADDOE to be more intuitive while staying true to the needs of the people using it.
We do not, and never will, incorporate AI into QADDOE.
Our mission
To democratize analysis by providing an affordable, user-friendly tool that empowers researchers of all backgrounds to turn raw data into meaningful insights. We are dedicated to breaking down the barriers that usually limit analysis, whether those are related to age, location, education, or financial resources.
We strongly believe the user should always be in total control to decide which questions to ask and how to interpret their findings. We also believe in future-proofing your work; your data will always be accessible regardless of which software you choose to use in the future. Ultimately, we want to build a community of informed minds where anyone can leverage the power of analysis for a deeper understanding of the world. By upholding these values, we aim to make the entire research experience more accessible and empowering for everyone.
What‚Äôs coming up
The application is currently in its beta phase, but we are moving quickly toward the release of version 1. This is a major milestone for the project and will introduce several significant changes. We are launching a brand new interface that has been redesigned from the ground up to provide better focus and clarity while you work. We are also focusing on improving the overall conviviality of the app to ensure the learning curve is much shallower for those new to the field. Finally, we have implemented significant speed optimizations to ensure that QADDOE stays lightweight and fast, even as your research projects grow in size and complexity.

computational-linguistics.title: computational linguistics
computational-linguistics.content:
In the study of linguistics, computational linguistics is an interdisciplinary field that combines linguistics and computer science to analyse and understand human language using computational methods.
There are two main applications for computational linguistics, (a) helping computers process and generate language as humans do, through tasks such as machine translation, speech recognition, and sentiment analysis; and (b) helping humans understand the intrinsic properties of a language by, for example, meta-analysis of the languages morphemes.
